Providence Hospital in 2009.

items.text: Economy
Aerospace, steel, ship building, retail, services, construction, medicine, and manufacturing are Mobile's major industries.
After having economic decline for several decades, Mobile's economy began to rebound in the late 1980s.
Between 1993 and 2003 roughly 13,983 new jobs were created as 87 new companies were founded and 399 existing companies were expanded.
[[CITE|228|http://city-data.com/us-cities/The-South/Mobile-Economy.html]]

Defunct companies that had been founded or based in Mobile included [[LINK|lang_en|Alabama_Drydock_and_Shipbuilding_Company|Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company]], [[LINK|lang_en|Delchamps|Delchamps]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Gayfers|Gayfers]]. [[CITE|270|http://bizjournals.com/jacksonville/stories/2010/05/17/daily13.html]] [[CITE|84|http://www.archives.state.al.us/famous/academy/a_delcha.html]] [[CITE|157|http://flotte2.com/MobileEconomics#gayfers]] Current companies that were formerly based in the city include [[LINK|lang_en|Checkers_(fast_food)|Checkers]], [[LINK|lang_en|Konica_Minolta|Minolta-QMS]], [[LINK|lang_en|Morrison_Management_Specialists|Morrison's]], and the [[LINK|lang_en|Waterman_Steamship_Corporation|Waterman Steamship Corporation]]. [[CITE|196|http://checkerscompany.com/our_story]] [[CITE|8|http://u-s-history.com/pages/h2255.html]]

In addition to those discussed below, [[LINK|lang_en|AlwaysHD|AlwaysHD]], [[LINK|lang_en|Foosackly's|Foosackly's]], [[LINK|lang_en|Integrity_Media|Integrity Media]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Volkert,_Inc.|Volkert, Inc.]] are headquartered in Mobile. [[CITE|37|http://alwayshd.com/about.php]] [[CITE|116|http://wkrg.com/mobilesmakeover/article/a_finger_for_boeing/15153]] [[CITE|8|http://u-s-history.com/pages/h2255.html]] [[CITE|233|http://volkert.com/history.htm]]

caption.text: Port of Mobile at Chickasaw Creek.

items.text: Major industry

caption.text: The [[LINK|lang_en|USNS_Spearhead_(JHSV-1)|USNS Spearhead (JHSV-1)]], another Austal USA-built ship, being prepared for its christening in the [[LINK|lang_en|BAE_Systems_Southeast_Shipyards|BAE Systems Southeast Shipyards]] floating drydock in September 2011. The *Spearhead* is the first ship of the [[LINK|lang_en|Spearhead_class_Joint_High_Speed_Vessel|Spearhead class Joint High Speed Vessel (JHSV)]].
Airbus Mobile Engineering Center at the Brookley Aeroplex in Mobile.

items.text: Port of Mobile

Mobile's [[LINK|lang_en|Port_of_Mobile|Alabama State Docks]] underwent the largest expansion in its history in the early 21st century. It expanded its container processing and storage facility and increased container storage at the docks by over 1,000% at a cost of over $300 million, a project completed in 2005. [[CITE|8|http://u-s-history.com/pages/h2255.html]] Despite the expansion of its container capabilities and the addition of two massive new cranes, the port went from 9th largest to the 12th largest by tonnage in the nation from 2008 to 2010. [[CITE|21|http://www.ndc.iwr.usace.army.mil/wcsc/pdf/wcusnatl10.pdf]] [[CITE|106|http://www.iwr.usace.army.mil/ndc/wcsc/pdf/wcusnatl08.pdf]]
Shipyards

Shipbuilding began to make a major comeback in Mobile in 1999 with the founding of [[LINK|lang_en|Austal_USA|Austal USA]]. [[CITE|190|http://coltoncompany.com/shipbldg/ussbldrs/postwwii/shipyards/active/aluminum/austal.htm]] A subsidiary of the Australian company [[LINK|lang_en|Austal|Austal]], it expanded its production facility for United States defense and commercial aluminum shipbuilding on [[LINK|lang_en|Blakeley_Island_(Alabama)|Blakeley Island]] in 2005. [[CITE|267|http://austal.com/index.cfm?objectid=B0B75979-65BF-EBC1-2349C7A56C359198]] Austal announced in October 2012, after winning a new defense contract and completing another 30,000 square feet (2,800 m 2 ) building within their complex on the island, that it will expand from a workforce of 3,000 workers to 4,500 employees. [[CITE|39|http://blog.al.com/press-register-business/2012/10/austal_unveils_new_navy_buildi.html]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Atlantic_Marine|Atlantic Marine]] operated a major shipyard at the former Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company site on [[LINK|lang_en|Pinto_Island|Pinto Island]]. It was acquired by British defense conglomerate [[LINK|lang_en|BAE_Systems|BAE Systems]] in May 2010 for $352 million. Doing business as [[LINK|lang_en|BAE_Systems_Southeast_Shipyards|BAE Systems Southeast Shipyards]], the company continues to operate the site as a full-service shipyard, employing approximately 600 workers with plans to expand. [[CITE|270|http://bizjournals.com/jacksonville/stories/2010/05/17/daily13.html]] [[CITE|136|http://baesystems.com/product/BAES_021153/bae-systems-ship-repair]]
Mobile Aeroplex at Brookley

The [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_Aeroplex_at_Brookley|Mobile Aeroplex at Brookley]] is an industrial complex and airport located 3 miles (5 km) south of the central business district of the city. It is the largest industrial and transportation complex in the region, having more than 70 companies, many of which are [[LINK|lang_en|Aerospace|aerospace]], spread over 1,650 acres (668 ha). [[CITE|213|http://brookleyaeroplex.com/aeroplex.php]] Notable employers at Brookley include [[LINK|lang_en|Airbus|Airbus]] North America Engineering ([[LINK|lang_en|EADS_North_America|Airbus Military North America]]'s facilities are at the Mobile Regional Airport), [[LINK|lang_en|ST_Aerospace_Mobile|ST Aerospace Mobile]] (a division of [[LINK|lang_en|ST_Engineering|ST Engineering]]), and [[LINK|lang_en|Continental_Motors,_Inc.|Continental Motors]]. [[CITE|17|http://brookleyaeroplex.com/pdfs/tenants.pdf]]

Plans for an [[LINK|lang_en|Airbus_A320_family|Airbus A320 family]] aircraft assembly plant in Mobile were formally announced by [[LINK|lang_en|Airbus|Airbus]] CEO [[LINK|lang_en|Fabrice_Brégier|Fabrice Brégier]] from the Mobile Convention Center on July 2, 2012. The plans include a $600 million factory at the Brookley Aeroplex for the assembly of the A319, A320 and A321 aircraft. It was planned to employ up roughly 1,000 full-time workers when fully operational. Construction began with a groundbreaking ceremony on April 8, 2013, with it becoming operable by 2015 and producing up to 50 aircraft per year by 2017. [[CITE|55|http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/officials-ala-airbus-plant-employ-1000-16690789#.T_HRzJHhcqN]] [[CITE|101|https://bbc.co.uk/news/business-18675711]] The assembly plant is the company's first factory to be built within the United States. [[CITE|146|https://nytimes.com/2012/07/03/business/global/eads-to-build-airbus-assembly-line-in-mobile-ala.html]] It was announced on February 1, 2013 that Airbus had hired Alabama-based [[LINK|lang_en|Hoar_Construction|Hoar Construction]] to oversee construction of the facility. [[CITE|181|http://airbus.com/newsevents/news-events-single/detail/airbus-appoints-program-manager-for-its-mobile-assembly-line]] The factory officially opened on September 14, 2015, covering one million square feet on 53 acres of flat grassland. [[CITE|219|http://airspacemag.com/flight-today/airbus-in-mobile-180959124]]

On October 16, 2017, Airbus announced a partnership with [[LINK|lang_en|Bombardier_Aerospace|Bombardier Aerospace]], taking over a majority share of the [[LINK|lang_en|Bombardier_CSeries|Bombardier CSeries]] airliner program. As a result of this partnership, Airbus plans to open an assembly line for CSeries aircraft in Mobile, particularly to serve the US market. This effort may allow the companies to circumvent high import tariffs on the CSeries family. [[CITE|259|https://bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-16/airbus-to-buy-majority-stake-in-bombardier-c-series-jet-program]] The aircraft was renamed the Airbus A220 on 10 July 2018; [[CITE|23|https://airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/07/airbus-introduces-the-a220-100-and-a220-300.html]] deliveries from the Mobile assembly line are expected to start in 2020. [[CITE|61|https://leehamnews.com/2018/06/08/airbus-c-series-deal-closes-july-1-presents-challenges-for-boeing-embraer]]
ThyssenKrupp

German technology conglomerate [[LINK|lang_en|ThyssenKrupp|ThyssenKrupp]] broke ground on a $4.65 billion combined [[LINK|lang_en|Stainless_steel|stainless]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Carbon_steel|carbon steel]] processing facility in Calvert, a few miles north of Mobile, in 2007. It was originally projected to eventually employ 2,700 people. The facility became operational in July 2010. [[CITE|161|http://thyssenkruppnewusplant.com]] [[CITE|199|http://blog.al.com/live/2007/05/mobile_county_wins_thyssenkrup.html]]

The company put both its carbon mill in Calvert and a steel slab-making unit in [[LINK|lang_en|Rio_de_Janeiro|Rio de Janeiro]] up for sale in May 2012, citing rising production costs and a worldwide decrease in demand. [[CITE|239|http://blog.al.com/live/2012/05/thyssenkrupp_considers_sale_of.html]] ThyssenKrupp's stainless steel division, Inoxum, including the stainless portion of the Calvert plant, was sold to Finnish stainless steel company [[LINK|lang_en|Outokumpu|Outokumpu Oyi]] in 2012. [[CITE|4|http://blog.al.com/press-register-business/2012/05/new_owners_of_thyssenkrupp_sta.html]]
Top employers

According to Mobile's 2011 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the top employers in the city during 2011 were: [[CITE|39|http://blog.al.com/press-register-business/2012/10/austal_unveils_new_navy_buildi.html]]

caption.text: Shelby Hall, College of Engineering and the School of Computer and Information Sciences, at the [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_South_Alabama|University of South Alabama]].

items.text: Unemployment rate

The [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Labor|United States Department of Labor]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Bureau_of_Labor_Statistics|Bureau of Labor Statistics]] unemployment rate (not seasonally adjusted) for the Mobile Metropolitan Statistical Area was 7.5% for July 2013, compared with an unadjusted rate of 6.6% for Alabama as a whole and 7.4% for the entire nation. [[CITE|72|http://data.bls.gov/cgi-bin/surveymost?la+01=]]
Transportation
Air

Local airline passengers are served by the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_Regional_Airport|Mobile Regional Airport]], with direct connections to four major hub airports. [[CITE|155|http://mobileairportauthority.com/properties.php]] It is served by [[LINK|lang_en|American_Eagle_(airline_brand)|American Eagle]], with service to [[LINK|lang_en|Dallas-Fort_Worth_International_Airport|Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Charlotte|Charlotte/Douglas International Airport]]; [[LINK|lang_en|United_Express|United Express]], with service to [[LINK|lang_en|George_Bush_Intercontinental_Airport|George Bush Intercontinental Airport]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Delta_Connection|Delta Connection]], with service to [[LINK|lang_en|Hartsfield-Jackson_International_Airport|Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport]]. [[CITE|155|http://mobileairportauthority.com/properties.php]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_Downtown_Airport|Mobile Downtown Airport]] at the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_Aeroplex_at_Brookley|Brookley Aeroplex]] serves corporate, cargo, and private aircraft. [[CITE|155|http://mobileairportauthority.com/properties.php]]

caption.text: The old [[LINK|lang_en|Gulf,_Mobile_and_Ohio_Passenger_Terminal|Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Passenger Terminal]] houses the Mobile Area Transportation Authority.
The [[LINK|lang_en|Cochrane–Africatown_USA_Bridge|Cochrane–Africatown USA Bridge]] spanning the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_River|Mobile River]].
Interior of the eastbound [[LINK|lang_en|George_Wallace_Tunnel|George Wallace Tunnel]] under the Mobile River.

items.text: Rail

Mobile is served by four [[LINK|lang_en|Class_I_railroad|Class I railroads]], including the [[LINK|lang_en|Canadian_National_Railway|Canadian National Railway]] (CNR), [[LINK|lang_en|CSX_Transportation|CSX Transportation]] (CSX), the [[LINK|lang_en|Kansas_City_Southern_Railway|Kansas City Southern Railway]] (KCS), and the [[LINK|lang_en|Norfolk_Southern_Railway|Norfolk Southern Railway]] (NS). [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Alabama_and_Gulf_Coast_Railway|Alabama and Gulf Coast Railway]] (AGR), a [[LINK|lang_en|Class_III_railroad|Class III railroad]], links Mobile to the [[LINK|lang_en|BNSF_Railway|Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway]] (BNSF) at [[LINK|lang_en|Amory,_Mississippi|Amory, Mississippi]]. These converge at the Port of Mobile, which provides [[LINK|lang_en|Intermodal_freight_transport|intermodal freight transport]] service to companies engaged in importing and exporting. Other railroads include the [[LINK|lang_en|CG_Railway|CG Railway]] (CGR), a rail ship service to [[LINK|lang_en|Coatzacoalcos|Coatzacoalcos]], [[LINK|lang_en|Veracruz|Veracruz]], and the [[LINK|lang_en|Terminal_Railway_Alabama_State_Docks|Terminal Railway Alabama State Docks]] (TASD), a [[LINK|lang_en|Switching_and_terminal_railroad|switching railroad]]. [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]] The city was served by [[LINK|lang_en|Amtrak|Amtrak]]'s *[[LINK|lang_en|Sunset_Limited|Sunset Limited]] * passenger train service until 2005, when the service was suspended due to the effects of [[LINK|lang_en|Hurricane_Katrina|Hurricane Katrina]]. [[CITE|208|http://amtrak.com/servlet/ContentServer?c=am2Copy&cid=1093554015790&pagename=Amtrak%2Fam2Copy%2FNews_Release_Page&ssid=170]] [[CITE|245|http://amtrak.com/timetable/apr07/P01.pdf]]
Roadways

Two major [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_highways|interstate highways]] and a spur converge in Mobile. [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_10|Interstate 10]] runs northeast to southwest across the city while [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_65|Interstate 65]] starts in Mobile at Interstate 10 and runs north. [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_165_(Alabama)|Interstate 165]] connects to Interstate 65 north of the city in [[LINK|lang_en|Prichard,_Alabama|Prichard]] and joins Interstate 10 in downtown Mobile. [[CITE|30|http://milebymile.com/maps/Alabama_road_map.pdf]] Mobile is well served by many major highway systems. United States Highways [[LINK|lang_en|U.S._Route_31_in_Alabama|US 31]], [[LINK|lang_en|US_43_(AL)|US 43]], [[LINK|lang_en|US_45_(AL)|US 45]], [[LINK|lang_en|US_90_(AL)|US 90]], and [[LINK|lang_en|US_98_(AL)|US 98]] radiate from Mobile traveling east, west, and north. Mobile has three routes east across the Mobile River and Mobile Bay into neighboring [[LINK|lang_en|Baldwin_County,_Alabama|Baldwin County, Alabama]]. Interstate 10 leaves downtown through the [[LINK|lang_en|George_Wallace_Tunnel|George Wallace Tunnel]] under the river and then over the bay across the [[LINK|lang_en|Jubilee_Parkway|Jubilee Parkway]] to [[LINK|lang_en|Spanish_Fort,_Alabama|Spanish Fort]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Daphne,_Alabama|Daphne]]. US 98 leaves downtown through the [[LINK|lang_en|Bankhead_Tunnel|Bankhead Tunnel]] under the river, onto [[LINK|lang_en|Blakeley_Island_(Alabama)|Blakeley Island]], and then over the bay across the [[LINK|lang_en|Battleship_Parkway|Battleship Parkway]] into Spanish Fort, Alabama. US 90 travels over the [[LINK|lang_en|Cochrane–Africatown_USA_Bridge|Cochrane–Africatown USA Bridge]] to the north of downtown onto Blakeley Island where it becomes co-routed with US 98. [[CITE|30|http://milebymile.com/maps/Alabama_road_map.pdf]]
Mobile's public transportation is the Wave Transit System which features buses with 18 fixed routes and neighborhood service.

[[CITE|127|http://thewavetransit.com]] Baylinc is a public transportation bus service provided by the Baldwin Rural Transit System in cooperation with the Wave Transit System that provides service between eastern [[LINK|lang_en|Baldwin_County,_Alabama|Baldwin County]] and downtown Mobile. Baylinc operates Monday through Friday. [[CITE|197|http://thewavetransit.com/files/BratSchedule.pdf]] [[LINK|lang_en|Greyhound_Lines|Greyhound Lines]] provides intercity bus service between Mobile and many locations throughout the United States. Mobile is served by several taxi and limousine services. [[CITE|271|http://al.com/mobile/cityguide?transportation.html=]]
Water

The [[LINK|lang_en|Port_of_Mobile|Port of Mobile]] has public, deepwater terminals with direct access to 1,500 miles (2,400 km) of inland and intracoastal waterways serving the [[LINK|lang_en|Great_Lakes|Great Lakes]], the [[LINK|lang_en|Ohio_River|Ohio]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Tennessee_River|Tennessee river]] valleys (via the [[LINK|lang_en|Tennessee-Tombigbee_Waterway|Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway]]), and the [[LINK|lang_en|Gulf_of_Mexico|Gulf of Mexico]]. [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]] The Alabama State Port Authority owns and operates the public terminals at the Port of Mobile. [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]] The public terminals handle [[LINK|lang_en|Containerization|containerized]], bulk, breakbulk, [[LINK|lang_en|Roll-on|roll-on/roll-off]], and heavy-lift cargoes. [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]] The port is also home to private bulk terminal operators, as well as a number of highly specialized shipbuilding and repair companies with two of the largest floating dry docks on the Gulf Coast. [[CITE|13|http://mobilechamber.com/infrastructure.asp]]

The city was a home port for [[LINK|lang_en|Cruise_ship|cruise ships]] from [[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Cruise_Lines|Carnival Cruise Lines]]. [[CITE|35|http://carnival.com/cms/fun/ships/carnival_elation/default.aspx?shipCode=EL]] The first cruise ship to call the port home was the *[[LINK|lang_en|Holiday_(ship)|Holiday]] *, which left the city in November 2009 so that a larger and newer ship could take its place. The *[[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Fantasy|Carnival Fantasy]] * operated from Mobile from then on until the *[[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Elation|Carnival Elation]] * arrived in May 2010. [[CITE|66|http://blog.al.com/live/2009/09/carnival_cruise_lines_to_deplo.html]] In early 2011, Carnival announced that despite fully booked cruises, the company would cease operations from Mobile in October 2011. This cessation of cruise service left the city with an annual [[LINK|lang_en|Interest|debt service]] of around two million dollars related to the terminal. [[CITE|162|http://www2.wkrg.com/news/2012/jan/19/rent-alabama-cruise-terminal-ar-3077353]] In September 2015, Carnival announced that the *[[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Fantasy|Carnival Fantasy]] * was relocating from Miami, Florida to Mobile, Alabama after a five-year absence and would offer four and five night cruises to Mexico that started in November 2016 through November 2017. The four night cruises will visit Cozumel, Mexico while the five night cruises will additionally visit Costa Maya or Progreso. [[CITE|205|http://carnival-news.com/2015/09/23/carnival-city-of-mobile-announce-year-long-season-of-cruises-from-port-of-mobile-aboard-carnival-fantasy-beginning-in-2016]] Her first departure from Mobile left on November 9, 2016 on a five night cruise to Cozumel and Progreso. Currently, she is scheduled to sail thru April 2018. [[CITE|254|https://icruise.com/ships/carnival-cruises-carnival-fantasy-cruise-itineraries.html]]

Although Carnival Cruise Lines did not operate from Mobile after the Carnival Fantasy left in 2011, the *[[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Triumph|Carnival Triumph]] * was towed into the port following a crippling engine room fire. [[CITE|20|http://blog.al.com/live/2013/03/city_of_mobile_to_charge_cruis.html]] It was the largest cruise ship ever to dock at the cruise terminal in Mobile. [[CITE|52|http://blog.al.com/live/2013/02/post_322.html]] Later it was eclipsed by the *[[LINK|lang_en|Carnival_Conquest|Carnival Conquest]] *, which docked in Mobile when the [[LINK|lang_en|Port_of_New_Orleans|Port of New Orleans]] was temporarily closed. [[CITE|130|https://webcitation.org/6I5h8EjME?url=http%3A%2F%2Fblog.al.com%2Flive%2F2013%2F07%2Fmore_than_4500_passengers_and.html]] Larger commercial ships routinely arrive at the Port of Mobile.
Media
Print

Mobile's *[[LINK|lang_en|Press-Register|Press-Register]] * is Alabama's oldest active newspaper, first published in 1813. [[CITE|209|https://web.archive.org/web/20080517135219/http://www.newhouse.com/the-press-register.html]] The paper focuses on [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_County,_Alabama|Mobile]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Baldwin_County,_Alabama|Baldwin]] counties and the city of Mobile, but also serves southwestern Alabama and southeastern Mississippi. [[CITE|209|https://web.archive.org/web/20080517135219/http://www.newhouse.com/the-press-register.html]] Mobile's alternative newspaper is the *[[LINK|lang_en|Lagniappe_(newspaper)|Lagniappe]] *. [[CITE|90|http://lagniappemobile.com/about]] The Mobile area's local magazine is *Mobile Bay Monthly*. [[CITE|184|http://pmtpublishing.com/default.aspx?id=42]] The *Mobile Beacon* is an alternative focusing on the African-American communities of Mobile. [[LINK|lang_en|Mod_Mobilian|Mod Mobilian]] is a website with a focus on cultured living in Mobile. [[CITE|226|http://modmobilian.com]]
Television
Mobile is served locally by a number of over-the-air television stations.

These include [[LINK|lang_en|WKRG|WKRG 5]] ([[LINK|lang_en|CBS|CBS]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WALA|WALA 10]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Fox_Broadcasting_Company|Fox]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WPMI-TV|WPMI 15]] ([[LINK|lang_en|NBC|NBC]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WMPV-TV|WMPV 21]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Religious_broadcasting|religious]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WDPM-DT|WDPM 23]] (religious), [[LINK|lang_en|Alabama_Public_Television|WEIQ 42]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Public_Broadcasting_Service|PBS]]), and [[LINK|lang_en|WFNA_(TV)|WFNA 55]] ([[LINK|lang_en|The_CW_Television_Network|CW]]). [[CITE|275|http://stationindex.com/tv/markets/Mobile-Pensacola]] The region is also served by [[LINK|lang_en|WEAR-TV|WEAR 3]] ([[LINK|lang_en|American_Broadcasting_Company|ABC]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WSRE|WSRE 31]] (PBS), [[LINK|lang_en|WHBR_(TV)|WHBR 34]] (religious), [[LINK|lang_en|WFGX|WFGX 35]] ([[LINK|lang_en|MyNetworkTV|MyNetworkTV]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WJTC|WJTC 44]] (independent), [[LINK|lang_en|WFBD|WFBD 48]] ([[LINK|lang_en|America_One|America One]]), [[LINK|lang_en|WPAN|WPAN 53]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Jewelry_Television|Jewelry Television]]), and [[LINK|lang_en|WAWD|WAWD 58]] (independent), all out of the [[LINK|lang_en|Pensacola,_Florida|Pensacola, Florida]] area. [[CITE|275|http://stationindex.com/tv/markets/Mobile-Pensacola]] Mobile is part of the Mobile–Pensacola– [[LINK|lang_en|Fort_Walton_Beach,_Florida|Fort Walton Beach]] [[LINK|lang_en|Designated_market_area|designated market area]], as defined by [[LINK|lang_en|Nielsen_Media_Research|Nielsen Media Research]]. It ranked 61st in the nation for the 2007–08 television season. [[CITE|85|http://nielsenmedia.com/nc/nmr_static/docs/2007-2008_DMA_Ranks.xls]]
Radio

Fourteen [[LINK|lang_en|FM_broadcasting|FM]] radio stations transmit from Mobile: [[LINK|lang_en|WAVH|WAVH]], [[LINK|lang_en|WBHY-FM|WBHY]], [[LINK|lang_en|WBLX-FM|WBLX]], [[LINK|lang_en|WDLT-FM|WDLT]], [[LINK|lang_en|WHIL_(FM)|WHIL]], [[LINK|lang_en|WKSJ-FM|WKSJ]], WKSJ-HD2, [[LINK|lang_en|WLVM|WLVM]], [[LINK|lang_en|WMXC|WMXC]], [[LINK|lang_en|WMXC|WMXC]]-HD2, [[LINK|lang_en|WQUA|WQUA]], [[LINK|lang_en|WRKH|WRKH]], [[LINK|lang_en|WRKH|WRKH]]-HD2, and [[LINK|lang_en|WZEW|WZEW]]. Nine [[LINK|lang_en|AM_broadcasting|AM]] radio stations transmit from Mobile: [[LINK|lang_en|WBHY_(AM)|WBHY]], [[LINK|lang_en|WABF_(AM)|WABF]], [[LINK|lang_en|WGOK|WGOK]], [[LINK|lang_en|WIJD|WIJD]], [[LINK|lang_en|WLPR-AM|WLPR]], [[LINK|lang_en|WMOB|WMOB]], [[LINK|lang_en|WNGL|WNGL]], [[LINK|lang_en|WNTM|WNTM]], and [[LINK|lang_en|WXQW|WXQW]]. The content ranges from Christian Contemporary to [[LINK|lang_en|Hip_hop|Hip hop]] to [[LINK|lang_en|Top_40|Top 40]]. [[CITE|132|http://thecityofmobile.com/radio/index.html]] [[LINK|lang_en|Arbitron|Arbitron]] ranks Mobile's radio market as 93rd in the United States as of autumn 2007. [[CITE|178|http://arbitron.com/downloads/redbook_fa07.pdf]]
Sports

caption.text: The first [[LINK|lang_en|South_Alabama_Jaguars|South Alabama Jaguars]] football game at [[LINK|lang_en|Ladd–Peebles_Stadium|Ladd–Peebles Stadium]].
The [[LINK|lang_en|Hank_Aaron_Stadium|Hank Aaron Stadium]].
Entrance to the Mitchell Center at the University of South Alabama.

items.text: Football

Mobile is the home of [[LINK|lang_en|Ladd–Peebles_Stadium|Ladd–Peebles Stadium]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|American_football|football]] stadium opened in 1948. With a current capacity of 40,646, Ladd–Peebles Stadium is the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_American_football_stadiums_by_capacity|fourth-largest stadium in the state]]. [[CITE|256|http://laddpeeblesstadium.com/default.asp]]

Ladd–Peebles Stadium has been home to the [[LINK|lang_en|Senior_Bowl|Senior Bowl]] since 1951, featuring the best college seniors in [[LINK|lang_en|College_football|NCAA football]]. [[CITE|47|http://seniorbowl.com/2007/gamerecaps1950s.htm]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Dollar_General_Bowl|Dollar General Bowl]], originally known as the Mobile Alabama Bowl and later the GMAC Bowl and GoDaddy.com Bowl, has been played at Ladd–Peebles Stadium since 1999. It features opponents from the [[LINK|lang_en|Sun_Belt_Conference|Sun Belt]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Mid-American_Conference|Mid-American]] conferences. [[CITE|102|http://godaddybowl.com/date-set-15th-annual-godaddy-bowl]]
Since 1988, Ladd–Peebles Stadium has hosted the Alabama-Mississippi All-Star Classic.
The top graduating high school seniors from their respective states compete each June.
[[CITE|198|http://ahsaasports.com/football/alms-allstar/history.asp]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_South_Alabama|University of South Alabama]] in Mobile established a football team in 2007, which went undefeated in its 2009 inaugural season. Their program moved to Division I/FBS in 2013 as a member of the [[LINK|lang_en|Sun_Belt_Conference|Sun Belt Conference]]. It currently plays at Ladd–Peebles Stadium. [[CITE|278|http://southalabama.edu/footballproposal]]
Baseball

Mobile's [[LINK|lang_en|Hank_Aaron_Stadium|Hank Aaron Stadium]] is the home of the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_BayBears|Mobile BayBears]] [[LINK|lang_en|Minor_league_baseball|minor league baseball]] team. [[CITE|41|http://mobilebaybears.com/hank.asp]] South Alabama baseball also has a proud tradition, producing professional stars such as [[LINK|lang_en|Luis_Gonzalez_(outfielder)|Luis Gonzalez]], [[LINK|lang_en|Juan_Pierre|Juan Pierre]], [[LINK|lang_en|Jon_Lieber|Jon Lieber]], [[LINK|lang_en|Adam_Lind|Adam Lind]], and [[LINK|lang_en|David_Freese|David Freese]].

Five members of the [[LINK|lang_en|Baseball_Hall_of_Fame|Baseball Hall of Fame]] called Mobile home, more than any city outside of New York City and Chicago: the five players were [[LINK|lang_en|Satchel_Paige|Satchel Paige]], [[LINK|lang_en|Billy_Williams_(left_fielder)|Billy Williams]], [[LINK|lang_en|Willie_McCovey|Willie McCovey]], [[LINK|lang_en|Hank_Aaron|Hank Aaron]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Ozzie_Smith|Ozzie Smith]].
Basketball
South Alabama basketball is a respected mid-major, regularly competing for the Sun Belt Conference championship.
They play their home games at the [[LINK|lang_en|Mitchell_Center|Mitchell Center]].
Other sports and facilities

The Archbishop Lipscomb Athletic Complex is home of [[LINK|lang_en|AFC_Mobile|AFC Mobile]], which is a [[LINK|lang_en|Gulf_Coast_Premier_League|Gulf Coast Premier League]] soccer team. [[CITE|87|http://blog.al.com/press-releases/2017/03/afc_mobile_to_play_2017_home_g.html]]
The public Mobile Tennis Center includes over 50 courts, all lighted and hard-court.
[[CITE|137|http://mobiletenniscenter.net]]

For golfers, Magnolia Grove, part of the [[LINK|lang_en|Robert_Trent_Jones_Golf_Trail|Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail]], has 36 holes. The Falls course was recently named the best par 3 course in America. [[CITE|191|http://rtjgolf.com/courses/magnolia_grove]] [[LINK|lang_en|The_Mitchell_Company_Tournament_of_Champions|The Mitchell Company Tournament of Champions]] was played annually at Magnolia Grove from 1999 through 2007. The [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_Bay_LPGA_Classic|Mobile Bay LPGA Classic]] took its place in 2008, also held at Mobile's Magnolia Grove. [[CITE|230|http://lpga.com/golf/tournaments/lpga/mobile-bay-lpga-classic.aspx]]

Mobile is home to the [[LINK|lang_en|Azalea_Trail_Run|Azalea Trail Run]], which races through historic midtown and downtown Mobile. This 10k run has been an annual event since 1978. [[CITE|276|http://cityofmobile.org/calendar_events.php?category=&day=&month=01&year=2007]] The Azalea Trail Run is one of the premier 10k road races in the United States, attracting runners from all over the world. [[CITE|73|http://vulcantri.com/index.php?Itemid=46&agid=448&day=25&month=03&option=com_events&task=view_detail&year=2006]]
Sister cities
Mobile has registered [[LINK|lang_en|Sister_city|sister city]] arrangements with the following cities: [[CITE|117|http://ncsmobile.org/sister_cities.php]]

items.text: Tunnels

In Mobile there is the [[LINK|lang_en|George_Wallace_Tunnel|George Wallace Tunnel]] that takes you under the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_River|Mobile River]]. Also there is the older [[LINK|lang_en|Bankhead_Tunnel|Bankhead Tunnel]] that also goes under the [[LINK|lang_en|Mobile_River|Mobile River]].
